title: Why is French more widely spoken in Africa than English? - Quora

response.answer_text: Simple: Colonization. Essentially, from the Middle Ages until WWII, every major European nation had decided they wanted a piece of Africa and held a claim on some of its territory. Most of the north and north-west chunk of Africa was “colonized” by the French. The British also had large ‘claims’, but more to the east as well as the central-south. Depending on where you are in Africa, English, Portuguese, Spanish, Dutch may seem like the predominant ‘European’ language for that area; proportionally, I’m not certain that French is the dominant European language throughout Africa, though it may seem like the one most widely used. Same is true with portions of Asia; the French had colonized the far east and formed Indochina, which they lost after the Battle of Dien Bien Phu (1954), hence why French is still common in Viet Nam, Laos, and Cambodia.

NO it’s not. Two dozens countries in Africa speak french against a dozen that speak english. And a dozen that speak arabic. That is due to colonization. But countries that speak english are larger and much more populated than those that speak french. Like Nigeria and South Africa. In number of people speaking a certain language the ranking is: English - 700 millionsArabic - over 100 millionsSwahili - 100 millionsFrench - 90 millionsSource: Afrika Ranker
